tier.item: A lexical accusative is ruled out by the fact that the promoted object does get nominative in the passive.
Accusative assignment is prima facie evidence for v/Agr2 in the unaccusative. We will see constructions
below where the passive must have a light verb; which seems independently needed to select the agent. I
accordingly follow Harley (1995), Legate (1998) in having light verbs in all intransitive constructions.
Pylkkänen (1998) argues that a passive light verb can assign Case.
It is also a reflexive pronoun and an "inherent" lexicalized morpheme.

At that time his mother had already completed twenty seasons in the theater, although she considered the vast majority of her primarily children's roles in plays by Jir&ek, Tyl, Kohout, and Mafenck to be the mildly compromising sins of youth. After all, she wa s studying in me fourth year of law school and she no w thought of her participation as an extra for the Theater of the Czechoslovak army hi Vinohrady as merely a noncommittal game (which of course did not prevent her from presenting the more or les s random fact that the expected date of birth coincided with the theater's vacation time to her more successful colleagues absolutely as a matter of proper professional discipline). However paradoxical it may sound, beneath the veneer of amateur enthusiasm Kvido's mother - the one-time star of school plays ~ was in reality very shy and noone else besides Zita was allowed to examine her.

Josef, despite his apriori skepticism concerning

Mrs.-Nsg Zita-Nsg, head-physician-Nsg Podolf-adj-Gsgf maternity hospital-

Zita, the head physician of the Podolf maternity hospital and for many years a friend of grandmother Lfba, who had known Kvido's mother since childhood, patiently tried to cater to her whim and promised her that she would reorganize the doctors* schedules so that on that critical day there would not be even one man assisting in the "With Zita in Podolf no birth ever hurts", rhymed grandmother Liba at lunch, and even Kvido's father's father, grandfather Josef, despite his apriori skepticism concerning everything communist, naturally making no exception for health care, was willing to admit mat the likelihood of Kvido's little head being crushed by the hospital tongs this time was indeed somewhat lower than it would be elsewhere. The only thing that no one had taken into account was a shaggy black German shepherd which suddenly appeared on the evening of the twenty-seventh of June in the crimson-colored sunlight on the embankment of the Vltava precisely at the moment when Kvido's mother was cumbersomely climbing out of a taxi, and which -- after quickly dashing up unheard - knocked her against the warm plaster of a house on the corner of Anenske* square.
